greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k), n>=1, 0<=k<=2n(n+1), read by rows: row n gives the coefficients of the chromatic polynomial of the Aztec diamond graph of order n, highest powers first.
comment: The Aztec diamond graph of order n has 2*n*(n+1) vertices with integer coordinates (x,y) obeying |x-1/2| + |y-1/2| <= n and (2*n)^2 edges connecting vertices having Euclidean distance 1. It can be derived from the Aztec diamond using vertices to represent tiles and edges to connect vertices of neighboring tiles. The chromatic polynomial has 2*n*(n+1)+1 coefficients.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..7, flattened
Propp, J., Enumeration of matchings: problems and progress, in L. J. Billera et al. (eds.), New Perspectives in Algebraic Combinatorics
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Aztec Diamond
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Chromatic Polynomial
example: The Aztec diamond graph of order 1 is the cycle graph C_4 with chromatic polynomial q^4 -4*q^3 +6*q^2 -3*q => [1, -4, 6, -3, 0].
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 03 2011
